title: Right now I see no reason for the collection section in the client to not feature an owned skins tab
body:
Anyone else agree? I'm honestly surprised the client doesn't already have this. Having to check every champion for owned skins becomes tedious and the shop doesn't display legacy skins. 

This has been suggested before but it still doesn't seem to be in sight, really hoping this can be brought to the attention of Riot.


(This would definitely help distinguish the new client from the old client)

replies.body: Well, next patch _if it works out and there's nothing that delays it_ we're getting item sets back and they said that they're going to add a skins tab in the future.   One thing at a time.
True, but it does feel like they should have finished these features _before_ making the new client mandatory, no?

Then they'd have to keep updating the old client files too.
This way they can get those people off that and onto the new client.
Or they could just get the damn thing ready and ship it right after the New Client transition.

Good idea, and then when something like the mac 1/4 screen bug or the Directx error happens (except worse since there's more features that would go live at the same time) they get to fix all the bugs at the same time and need to take the game offline. /s

Learn to construct sentences properly. I have to analyze what you say and then piece it together based on an assumption. Great!

Why does preparing a feature hinder optimization? They can update it internally and fix any future problems on the PBE. That's why the Open-Beta existed in the first place.

They probably do have it mostly prepped.  They are _releasing them_ one at a time.

The PBE build is also different than the live build.  There was a blog on it if I'm remembering correctly.  That's why some bugs (like the Dark Star Thresh and Challenger Nid FOW lag bugs) weren't detectable on Pbe but went live.

Pbe is also a smaller overall sample, so problems with specific computers and such are less likely to get picked up and fixed.  Once live, a bug that would _possibly_ affect a handful of Pbe testers _will_ affect many live users.

Even though the Client has been Live for quite a while now. Doesn't the Client send feedback of the system specs on it's own with performance reports?

Also, i think with more features, more people would've used the New Client during it's testing phases and therefore they'd be able to fix more problems. I mean it's gonna ship Live anyway in a matter of couple patches and someone will have issues regardless. It's just impractical to have it done so late instead of just optimize it beforehand on some people.

But then again, the New Client in itself is a clusterfuck with propably no hope of reaching the level of optimization the Legacy Client Update had since their definition of "optimization" is removing things that make the application enjoyable to use and then splitting it into "Normal" and "Low-Spec Mode" with the latter looking like the Alpha Client with it's lacking polish.

I don't know if it auto sends thorough reports; for useful reports people might need to use the HRT and send them in a ticket.
When I've found issues/bugs that's what I've had to do since Alpha.

Yeah, for sure.  There were a few hiccups for me during Alpha and many people went back to the old client because it was more familiar.  What did make it easier for the testers that stayed was that they added "submit a bug" and "client feedback" buttons to the bottom of the client though.  I used those a ton; much better than a boards thread.
I guess people just don't like change, we probably both know that :P

Idk, after using the new client for so long I went back to the old one for a last time to mod my item sets before the  retirement and it didn't really seem more responsive or anything.  The click sound for buttons also seemed hella annoying after not hearing it for so long.  I have a relatively new comp and I use low-spec mode.  "Normal" has some process in there that makes my fan go crazy; I actually have no idea what it is.  I've tried going through the processes one by one.  I might try again to find it.

Well there you go. You say that you have a relatively new pc and you still have to use Low-Spec mode. Also, i think the button sounds were annoying cuz they were loud. They're totally fine in the Legacy client otherwise and very quiet in comparison.

The New Client's entire optimization is garbage and just them chipping at animations in order to try and make it better...like that's enjoyable..

>The New Client's entire optimization is garbage and just them chipping at animations in order to try and make it better

During Alpha I ran "normal mode" all the time with all animations no problem.
I haven't found out what it is specifically.  When I do, I'll notify them so they can fix it.
Well good luck with that. Perhaps you'll end up fixing a single problem at least. Hopefully something significant enough if you ask me.
one thing at a time ... the perfect resume of the past 7 years of league devs.
What's the alternative?
doing 6 things at a time like i do on ym job, thats an alternative, there is a shitload of alternative .... you lack of imagination ?

Yup, I do.
Spell it out for me; pushing 6 things live at a time (even if they have them done) doesn't work when any one of them if bugged could take a large majority of the playerbase out.
That doesn't seem worth to me.

^ Anybody that works in development will tell you that this is standard procedure. Heck, anybody working in science will tell you the same thing. In all cases you make one controlled release at a time to ensure that any changes or complications can be monitored and repaired before moving on to the next. 

If you make 6 changes at once and something destabilizes (which 90% of the time some thing _will_ destabilize), you have to pull the entire stack out and add them back in one at a time to see what caused the problem anyway. That just amounts to time (and money) wasted. It's much healthier to implement one at a time and do each one right than it is to lump everything in at once and pray that it works out. In most development fields, lumping everything in is considered the lazy way--not the other way around.

Besides, it's better to have a fast fix than a long one. If something you added takes down your website (or your client in Riot's case), you instantly halt any and all revenue while that site is down while simultaneously pissing off your customers. That risk has to minimized and those repairs should be kept simple so that you don't lose revenue. As buggy as things may be, game crashes are rare for League compared to most other titles, and this process is the reason why.
